title: Natural (music)
text:
In <a href="music%20theory">music theory</a>, a natural is an <a href="accidental%20%28music%29">accidental</a> which cancels previous accidentals and represents the unaltered <a href="pitch%20%28music%29">pitch</a> of a <a href="Musical%20note">note</a>. A note is natural when it is neither <a href="Flat%20%28music%29">flat</a> () nor <a href="Sharp%20%28music%29">sharp</a> () (nor <a href="Double%20flat">double-flat</a> nor <a href="Double%20sharp">double-sharp</a> ). Natural notes are the notes A, B, C, D, E, F, and G represented by the white keys on the <a href="Musical%20keyboard">keyboard</a> of a <a href="piano">piano</a> or <a href="Organ%20%28music%29">organ</a>. On a modern <a href="Pedal%20harp">concert harp</a>, the middle position of the seven pedals that alter the tuning of the strings gives the natural pitch for each string.
The scale of <a href="C%20major">C major</a> is sometimes regarded as the central, natural or basic <a href="major%20scale">major scale</a> because all of its notes are natural notes, whereas every other major scale in the <a href="circle%20of%20fifths">circle of fifths</a> has at least one sharp or flat in it.
The notes F, C, E, B, and most notes inflected by double-flats and double-sharps correspond in pitch with natural notes; however, they are not regarded as natural notes but rather as <a href="enharmonic">enharmonic</a> equivalents of them and are just as much <a href="Diatonic%20and%20chromatic">chromatic</a>ally inflected notes as most sharped and flatted notes that are represented by black notes on a keyboard.
Natural sign.
In <a href="musical%20notation">musical notation</a>, a "natural sign" () is an <a href="accidental%20%28music%29">accidental</a> sign used to cancel a <a href="Flat%20%28music%29">flat</a> or <a href="Sharp%20%28music%29">sharp</a> from either a preceding note or the <a href="key%20signature">key signature</a>. 
\override Score.TimeSignature #'stencil = ##f
\relative c" { 
 \time 4/4 a!1
</score>
If a <a href="Bar%20%28music%29">bar</a> contains a double sharp or double flat <a href="Accidental%20%28music%29">accidental</a> and the <a href="composer">composer</a> wishes to denote the same note with only a single sharp or flat, a natural sign traditionally precedes the (single) sharp or flat symbol. Naturals are assumed (by default) in key signatures and mentioned only in key signature changes.
The natural sign is derived from a square "b" used to denote B in medieval music (in contrast with the round "b" denoting B, which became the flat symbol). The <a href="Unicode">Unicode</a> character '♮' (U+266E) should display as a natural sign. Its HTML entity is .
Double natural.
In a case where one needs to cancel both sharps or flats of a <a href="double%20sharp">double sharp</a> or <a href="double%20flat">double flat</a>, it is acceptable to write a single natural. In older practice, two naturals () can be written. Similarly, to cancel one flat or sharp from a double flat or sharp, the traditional convention is to use () or () respectively, but the naturals are generally omitted in modern notational practice.
